title: Update regarding EcoPower
story_body:
Velocity Motors's (VELO) flagship product, the VMX-1000 electric powertrain, has been recalled due to a critical failure in the battery management system (BMS). The recall affects over 10,000 units, which were shipped with faulty BMS firmware that caused thermal runaway in the EcoPower (ECO) lithium-nickel-manganese-cobalt-oxide (NMC) battery packs.

According to sources, the faulty firmware led to an improper state of charge (SoC) estimation, resulting in excessive heat generation and subsequent pack failure. The issue was first identified during a series of accelerated life tests, which revealed a statistically significant increase in failure rates above 300 charge cycles.

The recall is a significant blow to Velocity Motors, which has struggled to maintain its market share in the competitive electric powertrain space. In contrast, EcoPower, the supplier of the battery packs, stands to gain from the recall. As a direct competitor to Velocity Motors, EcoPower's own electric powertrain offerings may attract customers wary of Velocity Motors's quality control issues.

EcoPower's battery packs, while implicated in the recall, are not inherently flawed. In fact, EcoPower's NMC chemistry has been widely praised for its high energy density and cycle life. The issue lies squarely with Velocity Motors's BMS design and firmware implementation.

The recall highlights the importance of rigorous testing and validation in the development of complex powertrain systems. As the industry continues to push the boundaries of electric vehicle performance and efficiency, the need for robust and reliable engineering solutions will only intensify.

With Velocity Motors's reputation tarnished, EcoPower is well-positioned to capitalize on the situation. As the market leader in advanced battery technologies, EcoPower's electric powertrain offerings are likely to attract increased attention from OEMs and Tier 1 suppliers seeking reliable and high-performance solutions.
